Description: Ostracon, fragment of the body of a pale red-brown pottery vessel, the interior is slightly ribbed and bears very faint traces of a number lines of Coptic text written in black ink, the exterior is covered with a brown slip and remains of twenty-three lines of Coptic text written in black ink containing a literary letter.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Egypt, probably from the Theban Region
Bibliographic references: Biedenkopf-Ziehner 2000a / Koptische Ostraka I: Ostraka aus dem Britischen Museum in London (p.324-329, pl.49)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (82913) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/82913)
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Robert Curzon, 14th Baron Zouche
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Robert Curzon, 14th Baron Zouche
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: O.Brit.Mus.Copt. II 47 (text edition abbreviation according to Oates et al 2001)
